messages.text:
It should rebuild from scratch every 24 hours the first week after a release was tagged, to cover cases where binaries change shortly after release.

I misread the GH API docs, the endpoint I used doesn't include pre-releases. I had previously only tested it with full releases. My bad :face_palm: Should be a relatively quick fix.

---

I triggered a manual rebuild ~5 hours ago when someone reported that issue in the setup-julia repo and the rebuilt file includes the correct hash `7e6a0298eebe48d408279c6f99cb5df575b39097c44846971e5851a4daf25f0a`, so I think the issue should be resolved now

Should be a relatively quick fix.

messages.text:
Hey! I'm the main developer and maintainer of <https://github.com/biaslab/Rocket.jl|Rocket.jl> (library for reactive programming) and <https://github.com/biaslab/ReactiveMP.jl|ReactiveMP.jl> (library for reactive message passing based Bayesian Inference) packages. I have a problem with the 1.6 release, basically some parts of our code became ~2x slower and it also allocates ~2x more memory.  That is a clear and huge regression.

I tried running julia with `--track-allocation` , tried `SnoopCompile`  and `ProfileView` .  I've been debugging for a whole day but still have no clue what could be exactly the cause (however I made some interesting observations, which don't really make sense to me).

I have a suspicion that there is some regression in multiple dispatch when using traits. I posted an <https://github.com/JuliaLang/julia/issues/37045|issue> on Julia github repo some time ago and it is still haven't been fixed. However I managed to make a hot-fix for this issue in our codebase for Julia v1.5. But I'm not sure that this is the main problem, perhaps there is something else. Our code is open source, but its quite complex. I have a working example, but it is far from minimal. Any ideas how to proceed further?

elements.text: Hey! I'm the main developer and maintainer of
Rocket.jl
(library for reactive programming) and
ReactiveMP.jl

(library for reactive message passing based Bayesian Inference) packages. I have a problem with the 1.6 release, basically some parts of our code became ~2x slower and it also allocates ~2x more memory.  That is a clear and huge regression.

I tried running julia with
--track-allocation
, tried
SnoopCompile
and
ProfileView

.  I've been debugging for a whole day but still have no clue what could be exactly the cause (however I made some interesting observations, which don't really make sense to me).

I have a suspicion that there is some regression in multiple dispatch when using traits. I posted an
issue

on Julia github repo some time ago and it is still haven't been fixed. However I managed to make a hot-fix for this issue in our codebase for Julia v1.5. But I'm not sure that this is the main problem, perhaps there is something else. Our code is open source, but its quite complex. I have a working example, but it is far from minimal. Any ideas how to proceed further?

messages.text: That's unfortunate :(. I think opening an issue with what you have so far is always beneficial because it has the chance for more eyes on it and there is a good place to discuss it.

elements.text: That's unfortunate :(. I think opening an issue with what you have so far is always beneficial because it has the chance for more eyes on it and there is a good place to discuss it.

messages.text:
Thanks for your response! Yeah, I can post a new issue and will probably do it after more debugging. However nobody replied for several months under my previous issue which I posted on GH (<https://github.com/JuliaLang/julia/issues/37045|link>). It is a good point to start. It is still reproducible in Julia v1.6. I suspect this should be related.

TLDR on previous issue: Julia generates different output for `f(f(x))` and `f(g(x))` where `g`  is a copy-pasted version of `f` (literally). Different in terms of llvm code and performance.

elements.text: Thanks for your response! Yeah, I can post a new issue and will probably do it after more debugging. However nobody replied for several months under my previous issue which I posted on GH (
link

). It is a good point to start. It is still reproducible in Julia v1.6. I suspect this should be related.

TLDR on previous issue: Julia generates different output for
f(f(x))
and
f(g(x))
where
g
is a copy-pasted version of
f
(literally). Different in terms of llvm code and performance.

messages.text: Looks like that somehow got missed, sorry about that. As a side note, don't be afraid of bumping issues if it seems they are ignored. People do care, but with e.g. the GitHub interface, if you miss an issue and it falls off the top page of notifications you might never end up seeing it again.

elements.text: Looks like that somehow got missed, sorry about that. As a side note, don't be afraid of bumping issues if it seems they are ignored. People do care, but with e.g. the GitHub interface, if you miss an issue and it falls off the top page of notifications you might never end up seeing it again.

messages.text:
That is great! Interestingly, I just downloaded v1.4.2 (I haven't used it for a while) and it turned out that in v1.4 by benchmark performs even better in terms of memory consumption. If someone interested in the example itself here is the <https://github.com/biaslab/ReactiveMP.jl/blob/master/demo/Smoothing%20Benchmark.ipynb|link>. As I said this example is far from minimal and requires a lot of background in the field. In several words it does bayesian inference on a simple linear gaussian state space probabilistic model.

I have the following results of this benchmark on my laptop:
1. v1.4: 11.23 MiB 22.744 ms
2. v1.5 17.60 MiB 19.149 ms 
3. v1.6 35.40 MiB 23.691 ms
```OS: macOS (x86_64-apple-darwin18.7.0)
  CPU: Intel(R) Core(TM) i7-7660U CPU @ 2.50GHz
  WORD_SIZE: 64
  LIBM: libopenlibm
  LLVM: libLLVM-9.0.1 (ORCJIT, skylake)```
It allocates more and more memory for each version on the exactly same codebase :disappointed:

This is a toy example and time here does not really matter, but I also tested it for large and big probabilistic models. Memory consumption in v1.6 becomes a real issue and slowdowns an inference due to many GC cycles. I will continue with debugging the regression in v1.6 on the next week.

elements.text: That is great! Interestingly, I just downloaded v1.4.2 (I haven't used it for a while) and it turned out that in v1.4 by benchmark performs even better in terms of memory consumption. If someone interested in the example itself here is the
link

. As I said this example is far from minimal and requires a lot of background in the field. In several words it does bayesian inference on a simple linear gaussian state space probabilistic model.

I have the following results of this benchmark on my laptop:

OS: macOS (x86_64-apple-darwin18.7.0)
  CPU: Intel(R) Core(TM) i7-7660U CPU @ 2.50GHz
  WORD_SIZE: 64
  LIBM: libopenlibm
  LLVM: libLLVM-9.0.1 (ORCJIT, skylake)
It allocates more and more memory for each version on the exactly same codebase

This is a toy example and time here does not really matter, but I also tested it for large and big probabilistic models. Memory consumption in v1.6 becomes a real issue and slowdowns an inference due to many GC cycles. I will continue with debugging the regression in v1.6 on the next week.

messages.text: My main suspicion is that inference perhaps got a bit less precise so something that used to infer down to something concrete perhaps doesn't anymore. Looking with `@code_warntype` and comparing betwen 1.6 and 1.4 might give something that is then easier to reduce in size.

elements.text: My main suspicion is that inference perhaps got a bit less precise so something that used to infer down to something concrete perhaps doesn't anymore. Looking with
@code_warntype
and comparing betwen 1.6 and 1.4 might give something that is then easier to reduce in size.

messages.text: Something in the way Julia writes files into `.julia` makes the folder require Admin privileges once the user wants to delete `.julia`. Why is that? I thought it was an issues solved in `1.6`.

elements.text: Something in the way Julia writes files into
.julia
makes the folder require Admin privileges once the user wants to delete

messages.text: 1.6 + one week. Seems to be going ok?

elements.text: 1.6 + one week. Seems to be going ok?

messages.text: We've racked up a few backports for 1.6.1 but overall yeah

elements.text: We've racked up a few backports for 1.6.1 but overall yeah

messages.text: I have had a few "growing pains" with the CRLs I have to say. Mostly because of corporate proxy, otherwise fine.

messages.text: When there are new releases, do you try to build for armv7l or you simply gave up?  for example, v1.5.4 reportedly builds for that platform: <https://discourse.julialang.org/t/bring-julia-code-to-embedded-hardware-arm/19979/59>

attachments.title: Bring Julia code to embedded hardware (ARM)
attachments.text: Julia v1.5.4 does compile from source. I expect v1.6.1 to compile with the backport of Fix armv7l trampoline by staticfloat · Pull Request #40176 · JuliaLang/julia · GitHub already merged. Issue armv7l - No loaded BLAS libraries were built with LP64 support · Issue #40199 · JuliaLang/julia · GitHub prevents building current master. I will continue to test and report issues.
attachments.fallback: JuliaLang: Bring Julia code to embedded hardware (ARM)

messages.text: Julia v1.5.4 changed the layout of an internal structure, `jl_task_t`, compared to v1.5.3: <https://github.com/TuringLang/Turing.jl/pull/1568#issuecomment-815368746|https://github.com/TuringLang/Turing.jl/pull/1568#issuecomment-815368746> I'm not sure whether this should have happened

elements.text: Julia v1.5.4 changed the layout of an internal structure,
jl_task_t
, compared to v1.5.3:
https://github.com/TuringLang/Turing.jl/pull/1568#issuecomment-815368746
I'm not sure whether this should have happened

messages.text: It's defined in `julia.h`. I don't know how much API stability we have promised in the past, but yes that should probably not have been backported.

elements.text: It's defined in
julia.h
. I don't know how much API stability we have promised in the past, but yes that should probably not have been backported.

messages.text: If it were in `julia_internal.h` I would have claimed that it's not part of any API guarantee

julia_internal.h
